org.fpe4j

Class FF3

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.fpe4j.FF3

  • public class FF3
extends java.lang.Object
    Implementation of the FF3 method for format-preserving encryption defined in NIST SP 800-38G.

    To use this class, construct an instance and call the encrypt() and/or decrypt() methods.

    Author:
    Kai Johnson

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      FF3(int radix)
      Construct a new FF3 instance with a given radix.

      int[] encrypt(javax.crypto.SecretKey K, byte[] T, int[] X)

      Returns the maximum length of plaintext and ciphertext inputs based on the radix.
      int getMinlen()

    • Method Detail

      • decrypt

        public int[] decrypt(javax.crypto.SecretKey K,
                     byte[] T,
                     int[] X)
              throws java.security.InvalidKeyException
        NIST SP 800-38G Algorithm 10: FF3.Decrypt(K, T, X) - Decrypt a ciphertext string of numerals and produce a plaintext string of numerals of the same length and radix.

        Prerequisites:
        Designated cipher function, CIPH, of an approved 128-bit block cipher;
        Key, K, for the block cipher;
        Base, radix;
        Range of supported message lengths, [minlen..maxlen].

        Inputs:
        Numeral string, X, in base radix of length n, such that n is in the range [minlen..maxlen];
        Tweak bit string, T, such that LEN(T) = 64.

        Output:
        Numeral string, Y, such that LEN(Y) = n.

        Parameters:
        K - The 128-, 192- or 256-bit AES key.
        T - 8-byte tweak array.
        X - The plaintext numeral string.
        Returns:
        The ciphertext numeral string of the same length and radix.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If any of the arguments are null.
        java.security.InvalidKeyException - If K is not a valid AES key.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If T is not 8 bytes long; the length of X is not within the range [minlen..maxlen]; or any value X[i] is not in the range [0..radix].

      • encrypt

        public int[] encrypt(javax.crypto.SecretKey K,
                     byte[] T,
                     int[] X)
              throws java.security.InvalidKeyException
        NIST SP 800-38G Algorithm 9: FF3.Encrypt(K, T, X) - Encrypt a plaintext string of numerals and produce a ciphertext string of numerals of the same length and radix.

        Prerequisites:
        Designated cipher function, CIPH, of an approved 128-bit block cipher;
        Key, K, for the block cipher;
        Base, radix;
        Range of supported message lengths, [minlen..maxlen].

        Inputs:
        Numeral string, X, in base radix of length n, such that n is in the range [minlen..maxlen]
        Tweak bit string, T, such that LEN(T) = 64.

        Output:
        Numeral string, Y, such that LEN(Y) = n.

        Parameters:
        K - The 128-, 192- or 256-bit AES key.
        T - 8-byte tweak array.
        X - The plaintext numeral string.
        Returns:
        The ciphertext numeral string of the same length and radix.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If any of the arguments are null.
        java.security.InvalidKeyException - If K is not a valid AES key.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If T is not 8 bytes long; the length of X is not within the range [minlen..maxlen]; or any value X[i] is not in the range [0..radix].
